entry.et: Middle English deeth, from Old English dēath; akin to Old Norse dauthi death, deyja to die die

def.dt: :a permanent cessation of all vital functions :the end of life compare brain death
:an instance of dying a disease causing many deaths
:the cause or occasion of loss of life drinking was the death of him
:a cause of ruin the slander that was death to my character Wilkie Collins
:the destroyer of life represented usually as a skeleton with a scythe
:the state of being dead
:the passing or destruction of something inanimate the death of vaudeville
:extinction
:civil death
:slaughter
:the lie of life in matter :that which is unreal and untrue
:close to death :critically ill
:beyond endurance :excessively bored to death
:money payable to the beneficiary of a deceased
:any of several plants (genus Zigadenus) of the lily family that cause poisoning of livestock in the western United States
:a concentration camp in which large numbers of prisoners are systematically killed

:a very poisonous mushroom (Amanita phalloides) of deciduous woods of North America and Europe that varies in color from pure white to olive or yellow and has a prominent volva at the base called also death cup
:death tax
:an extremely tight grip caused especially by fear
:hold 3b maintained their death grip on overseas markets

:an innate and unconscious tendency toward self-destruction postulated in psychoanalytic theory to explain aggressive and destructive behavior not satisfactorily explained by the pleasure principle called also Thanatos compare eros 2
:a cast taken from the face of a dead person
:a type of heavy metal music that is characterized by the use of dark, violent, or gory imagery
